Graphical abstract An electrospinning separator with bimetallic Ni–Co MOF as sandwich material has the synergistic effect of adsorption and catalysis on polysulfide in Li–S batteries. Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries with high energy density are considered promising energy storage devices for the next generation. Nevertheless, the shuttle effect and the passive layer between the separator and the electrodes still seriously affect the cycle stability and life. Herein, a bimetallic Ni–Co metal–organic framework (MOF) with adsorption and catalytic synergism for polysulfides was successfully synthesized as an electrospinning separator sandwich for Li–S batteries. Introducing porous Ni–Co MOF coatings into the separator provides more adsorption catalytic sites for polysulfides, prevents their diffusion to the anode, and enhances sulfur utilization. Consequently, the improved Li–S batteries with a Ni–Co MOF@PAN (NCMP) electrospun separator delivered excellent rate performance and outstanding cycle stability, yielding an ultra-high initial capacity of 1560 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. Notably, remarkable Li–S battery performance with a discharge capacity of 794 mA h g−1 (84.1% capacity retention) was obtained after 500 cycles, while delivering a low capacity decay rate of 0.032% during long-term cycling (up to 500 cycles) at 1 C. Surprisingly, even at the current density of 2 C, the capacity attenuation rate of 2000 cycles is only 0.034% per cycle. In addition, compared with the Celgard separator, the NCMP separator also had high thermal stability (keeping the separator outline at 200 °C) that ensured battery safety and excellent electrolyte wettability (73% porosity and 535% electrolyte absorption) and significantly enhanced the ionic conductivity and Li+ transfer number, and protected the surface integrity of the anode. Keywords Li–S batteries Ni–Co MOF Adsorption catalysis Synergistic effect 1 Introduction The development of advanced energy storage systems is critical to meet the growing demand for the storage of electric vehicles, portable devices, and renewable energy. Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have high theoretical specific capacity and specific energy, reaching 1675 mA h g−1 and 2600 W h kg−1, respectively [1–3]. The energy density of Li–S batteries is approximately ten times that of commercial cathode materials. In addition, the active substance sulfur of Li–S batteries is earth-abundant, inexpensive, and environmentally friendly, which is conducive to reducing the production cost of batteries and reducing environmental pollution [4,5]. Li–S batteries have attracted considerable research attention for new high-performance batteries. Nevertheless, there are still many problems with the practical application of Li–S batteries, such as the shuttle effect of soluble polysulfide intermediates, lithium dendrite growth, thermal stability, and safety of Li–S batteries [6,7]. The shuttle effect of polysulfides reduces the cycle performance of Li–S batteries [8–10]. Carriers with physical or chemical adsorption of polysulfides are required to inhibit the shuttle effect from maximizing the cycle life of Li–S batteries [11,12]. Building a barrier layer on the surface of the battery separator is a cost-effective and direct method, which can prevent polysulfide from migrating from cathode to anode [13–16]. The design and development of a multifunctional coating separator are effective strategies for improving the performance of Li–S batteries [17–20]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have small pore sizes [21–23]. The advantages of these materials lie in their porous structure and optional particle size. Porous materials are ideal host materials because of their high inhibition ability in the volume change process [24,25]. Sulfur atoms can combine with metal ions in the network because of the porous structure of MOFs, which supports better sulfur adsorption. Moreover, the functional groups (such as oxygen, nitrogen, and boron) in MOFs can form bonds with lithium polysulfide, improving the structure and cycle stability of Li–S batteries [26,27]. The high specific surface area of MOFs determines the content of the active substance sulfur, which helps achieve the maximum possible specific capacity in Li–S batteries. In addition, these pores can maintain a high electrolyte absorption rate to fix the sulfur and allow physical adsorption [28,29]. On the other hand, the physical adsorption of polysulfides is far from sufficient. Active catalytic materials are needed to enhance the conversion reaction kinetics between soluble polysulfides and Li2S2/Li2S and inhibit the shuttle effect of polysulfides and improve the utilization rate of high-loaded sulfur. MOFs with catalytic effects are more effective than pure polar material adsorption [30]. Monoatomic catalysts have been reported to significantly catalyze sulfur oxidation–reduction reactions in Li–S batteries [31]. Monoatomic catalysts with theoretical atomic utilization of 100% have become a hot research direction in traditional industrial catalysis and emerging electrocatalysis. Monoatomic catalysts have high catalytic activity because of their completely bare catalytic active surface and can minimize the amount of catalyst used. Attracting mono-atom catalysts to Li–S batteries can improve their performance and reduce the loss of energy density by catalyst adders [32,33]. In addition, mono-atom catalysts also exhibit high sulfur affinity, which facilitates the fixation of lithium polysulfide and inhibits the shuttle effect [34]. Monoatomic Ni and Co are effective catalysts for Li–S batteries and have recently been used to synthesize various metal–organic frameworks [35,36]. The results show that Ni-MOF is more effective in reducing long-chain polysulfides, accelerating the transition of long-chain polysulfides to short-chain Li2S2/Li2S. Co-MOF is beneficial to the kinetics of Li2S deposition [30]. Ni and Co have similar ion radii, so no significant structural changes are observed during the formation of bimetallic organic framework mixtures [37]. Compounds exhibit synergistic effects when these materials are bound to carbon-based materials. Bimetal atomic catalysts have multiple functions, which can chemisorb LiPS and enhance the kinetics of redox reaction to avoid the saturation of polysulfides, anchor more polysulfides to inhibit the sulfur shuttle effect, and improve the rate performance of batteries [38–40]. A bimetal Ni–Co MOF was synthesized to synergistically adsorb and catalyze LiPS to improve the cycle stability and rate performance of Li–S batteries. The Celgard series is the main separator used for Li–S batteries [41]. The polyolefin separator has a low liquid absorption rate and cannot solve the “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfide dissolved in electrolytes [42]. Moreover, Polyolefin materials are among the most flammable polymers, which will thermal shrinkage at high temperatures leading to internal short circuits and thermal runaway events and explosion in extreme cases due to their poor thermal stability. Therefore, the development of a heat-resistant separator is of the utmost importance to Li-S batteries. On the other hand, electrospinning is a mature technology for preparing nanofiber separators [43]. The electrospinning separator has high porosity, small thickness, large specific surface area, high thermal stability, good wettability with electrolytes, high liquid absorption, and ionic conductivity [44–46]. Among the polymers used to prepare electrospun separators, PAN is a matrix separator with good electrochemical performance and thermal stability. An electrospun separator coating bimetal Ni–Co MOF is synthesized to provide a solution for solving the challenges encountered by Li–S batteries. The main innovation of the present work is the preparation of a modified separator for Li–S battery by combining electrospinning technology and bimetallic MOF, which has not been reported so far. The advantages of high porosity, high electrolyte absorption, high-temperature safety of electrospinning separator and the adsorption and catalytic action of porous Ni-Co MOF on polysulfides are applied in this work. The results show that NCMP separators exhibit rapid lithium-ion conduction and satisfactory adsorption and catalytic conversion of polysulfides. The prepared NCMP batteries delivered an excellent electrochemical performance with an initial capacity of 1560 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. In addition, the battery has excellent cycling stability with a capacity per cycle decay rate is 0.032% (500 cycles at 1 C) and 0.034% (2000 cycles at 2 C), respectively. Compared with commercial Celgard separators, the NCMP separator has the advantages of high porosity, good electrolyte absorption, outstanding ionic conductivity and Li+ transfer number. More importantly, the NCMP separator maintains overall thermal stability even at 200 °C, thus ensuring the safety of Li–S battery in practical applications. These results demonstrate the great advantages of NCMP separator in the regulation of polysulfide. Therefore, This work reports the potential of bimetal MOF nanofiber separator NCMP as an efficient functional separator and provides a new approach for the development of a high-performance Li–S battery. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Polyacrylonitrile (PAN, Mw = 150,000) and N, N dimethylformamide (DMF, anhydrous, 99.8%) supplied by Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO 63,103 USA). Nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Mw = 290.70), cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Mw = 291.03), and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (C6H9NO) n were purchased from DAEJUNG. Trimesic acid (BTC, Mw = 210.14) was obtained from ALDRICH. Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, Mw = 364.45) was bought from JUNSEI. Celgard 2500 and 2032 coin cell parts were purchased from MTI Korea Corporation. All chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Synthesis of Ni–Co MOF and cathode Anhydrous ethanol (210 mL, C2H5OH), pure water, and dimethylformamide (DMF) were mixed in a ratio of 1:1:1 and stirred for 10 min to make a mixture. The mixed solution was taken, and nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) (the ratio is 1:1) were added to a concentration of 17.7 mmol L−1, labeled as solution A. Trimesic acid (BTC) was added to the remaining 130 mL of the mixed solution at a concentration of 22.5 mmol L−1. Urea (1200 mg) was then added to solution A. After stirring for 10 min to dissolve the material, the BTC mixture was added dropwise to solution A at a rate of 2–3 mL min−1 and mixed well to obtain the precursor solution. The precursor solution was then added to the reactor. The hydrothermal reaction was carried out at 170 °C for 6 h. The resulting light green precipitate was washed twice by centrifugation with pure water and anhydrous ethanol, respectively, and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 10 h to obtain Ni–Co MOF. The sulfur cathode was prepared by mixing 70 wt% sulfur, 20 wt% carbon black (CB), and 10 wt% PVDF into NMP. The slurry was coated on aluminum foil and vacuum-dried overnight at 55 °C. The sulfur content of the cathode was controlled within 1.2–2.0 mg cm−2 by adjusting the coating thickness. 2.3 Synthesis of Ni–Co MOF @Celgard and Ni–Co MOF @PAN modified separator PAN solution with a concentration of 10 wt% was prepared and spun after magnetic stirring at room temperature for 24 h. The electrospun nanofibers are collected on a drum covered with tin foil paper. The residual solvent on the separator was removed by drying in a drying oven at 50 °C for 24 h, and the separator was pressurized mechanically at 25 MPa for 30 min. The synthesized Ni–Co MOF, graphene, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) (mass ratio of 7:2:1) were uniformly dispersed in n-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) and alcohol by ultrasonic wave for 10 min and then stirred by magnetic stirring for 24 h. Subsequently, the slurry in NMP was coated on the polypropylene separator (Celgard 2500) and the slurry in alcohol was coated on the PAN separator to obtain a modified separator, marked as Ni–Co MOF@Celgard (NCMC) and Ni–Co MOF@PAN (NCMP). Furthermore, the modified separator was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 8 h. Finally, the separator was cut into round discs with a diameter of 19 mm after drying. Fig. 1 shows the function of the NCMP separator. 2.4 The Ni–Co MOF and separators testing and characterization The morphology and microstructure of Ni–Co MOF and the separator were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM/EDS S-4800), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, HITACHI H-7600). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to evaluate the bonding state further. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG-DTA (SDT Q600)) was used to analyze the thermal stability of the sample (0–500 °C), and the heating rate was 10 °C min−1. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was obtained in the range of 2θ 10°–80° 2θ radiation, and Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was carried out over the wavelength range of 500–4000 cm−1. The thermal shrinkage behavior of the separator was measured after being placed in an oven at 150 °C and 200 °C for 0.5 h. 2.5 Comparison of the polysulfide adsorption capacity between Ni–Co MOF and different separator Ni–Co MOF powder is placed into a 10 mL polysulfide solution. At the same time, another empty bottle of polysulfide solution was set as the control group, and the color change of the solution was observed in the argon environment for 10 h. The commercial Celgard, PAN, NCMC, and NCMP separators are placed in the middle of the H-type electrolytic cell to observe the solution color change after standing in argon for 24 h. The left bottle contains a polysulfide solution, and the right bottle contains the same solution without polysulfide. The Li2S6 adsorption capacity of Ni-Co MOF was measured by placing Ni-Co MOF powder (0.07 g) in a 10 mL bottle containing sufficient Li2S6 solution (0.01 mol L−1). 2.6 Electrolyte uptake and porosity The electrolyte uptake of the separator was calculated by measuring the weight difference of the separator before and after immersion in the electrolyte and calculated by the Eq. (1). W 1 is the weight of the drying separator, and W 2 is the weight after absorbing the electrolyte. (1) E l e c t r o l y t e u p t a k e % = W 2 - W 1 W 1 × 100 The porosity was calculated by measuring the difference in the mass of the separator before and after immersion in butanol. The separator was cut into a circle with a diameter of 1.5 cm. The porosity of the separator was calculated using Eq. (2). (2) P o r o s i t y % = M w - M d ρ × V × 100 where ρ is the density of n-butanol; V is the volume of the separator; M d and M w are the dry weight and wet weight of the separator, respectively. 2.7 Li + transference number The Li+ transference numbers of the different separators were examined using the potentiostat polarization method and EIS. The Li/separator/Li symmetrical battery was prepared to test the EIS and CA. A polarization potential of 10 mV was applied to the battery. The Li+ transference number was calculated using the Bruce-Vincent Eq. (3). (3) t L i + = I s ( Δ V - R o I o ) I o ( Δ V - R s I s ) where t Li + is the number of positive ion migrations; Δ V is the voltage applied to both ends of the battery; I o and R o are the initial currents and initial resistance, respectively; I s and R s are the steady-state current and steady-state resistance, respectively. 2.8 Electrochemical measurements Cyclic voltammetry (CV), linear scanning voltammetry (LSV), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and migration number (t Li +) tests of the assembled battery were conducted using an electrochemical workstation (SP-200, Biologics). The potential of the CV test was 1.7–2.9 V, and the scanning rate was 0.5 mV s−1. The electrochemical stability of the separator (0–5.0 V) was evaluated using LSV tests with lithium metal and stainless steel electrodes (Li ‖ SS batteries). The frequency of the EIS test was 100 mHz–7 MHz, and the amplitude was + 3 mV. The resistance of the separator was evaluated by EIS using two stainless steel electrode (SS ‖ SS) symmetrical batteries. The ion conductivity of the separator (σ) was calculated using formula (4): R, D, and S are the separator resistance, thickness, and area, respectively. (4) σ = D R × S In addition, the Li2S6 catalytic capacity of Ni–Co MOF was measured by assembling a symmetric battery containing/not-containing a Ni–Co MOF -coated polar plate, respectively. The symmetric battery electrolyte was 0.5 M Li2S6 and 1 M lithium bis (trifluoromethane sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) dissolved in a DOL/DME (1:1 v/v) solution. Coin batteries (2032) are made in glove boxes filled with Ar at room temperature. The electrolyte was prepared by dissolving 1.0 M lithium bis(trifluoromethane) sulfonamide (LiTFSI) in a 1:1 (v/v) mixture of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and dimethoxyethane (DME) solution. The electrolyte to sulfur (E/S) ratio was 10 μL mg−1. The separator performance was evaluated by measuring the charging and discharging rate capacity and cycle performance of the coin battery. The multi-channel battery test system conducts charge/discharge tests on the assembled battery under a constant current (CC) load. The specific capacity at the rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 C is studied in the voltage range of 1.7 to 2.9 V. The battery cycle test (Neware BTS3000) was conducted at room temperature. 2.9 Theoretical calculation. The Viena Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) was used for first-principles computational simulation. The Perdew-Buke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional under generalized gradient approximation (GGA) is used to describe the exchange–correlation between electrons. The truncation energy of all plane wave base groups is set to 400 eV. In the calculation of surface adsorption, 2 × 2 × 1 K-point grid sampling is performed in the first Brillouin region using the Monkhorst-Pack scheme of Γ center. The vacuum layer of the surface adsorption model is set at 15 Å to avoid the interaction between adsorbed molecules. All calculations use a Gaussian fitting scheme and set a small broadening (0.1) to deal with electron occupancy near the Fermi level, ensuring that the electron entropy applied to each atom is less than 1 meV. Meanwhile, the DFT-D3(BJ damping) method of the Grimme scheme was used for dispersion correction. Adsorption energy ( E ads ) is defined by the following Eq. (5). (5) E ads = E sub + Li 2 S n - E s u b + E L i 2 S n Where E sub + Li 2 S n represents the energy of polysulfide adsorbed on the substrate surface, E sub represents the energy of clean surface, and E Li 2 S n represents the energy of polysulfide molecules. Therefore, the more negative the calculated adsorption energy value means the stronger the interaction between the surface and the adsorption molecules. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterize the obtained sample morphology and structure. The fibers in the PAN separator were stacked against each other to form a 3D porous network structure (Fig. 2 a). The nanofibrous separator has excessive pores. Macropores are not conducive to holding cell voltage because of self-discharge and are prone to breakdown at high charge rates or under harsh conditions. The Ni–Co MOF consisted of sea urchin-like microspheres (Fig. 2b and c). The microspheres were constructed of numerous needle-like nanorods (Fig. 2d and Fig. S1). SEM revealed hollow sea urchin-like microparticles with huge voids. The morphological details of the Ni–Co MOFs were investigated by TEM equipped with EDS mapping. Fig. 2(e) and Fig. S1 present TEM images of the Ni–Co MOF overall structure, verifying its hierarchical hollow and sea urchin-like structures. TEM suggested that the needle-like nanorods were composed of many interconnected nanoparticles (Fig. S1). Fig. 2(e–j) showed that the C, N, O Ni, and Co elemental distributions were highly uniform. EDS also indicated the presence of various elements (Fig. 2p), further verifying the successful synthesis of high-quality Ni–Co MOFs. The modified separator showed excellent flexibility in the forward and backward flexion (Fig. 2l–o). Fig. 2(q–t) and Fig. S1(n–o) show the thickness of the different separators. To deeply study the synergistic catalytic activity of Ni–Co MOF, the interaction between Ni MOF, Co MOF, Ni–Co MOF and LIPS was investigated by density functional theory (DFT). The calculated adsorption binding energies can be used to explain the affinities of different polysulfide intermediates (Fig. 1u). The binding energy of Co–MOF to soluble long-chain (poly)sulfides (S8 and Li2S8) is higher than that of Ni-MOF. On the other hand, Ni–MOF has higher chain (poly)sulfide short sulfur species (Li2S2 and Li2S) than Co–MOF. However, the bimetallic Ni–Co MOF exhibits the highest binding energy to all LiPSs, indicating its strongest interaction and chemical anchoring to soluble LiPSs, which greatly contributes to the enhanced battery performance. Fig. 1(w) shows the Gibbs free energy of the discharge process from S8 to Li2S on Ni–MOF, Co–MOF, and Ni–Co MOF. Especially in the speed-limiting step of the whole conversion process (from Li2S4 to Li2S2), the Gibbs free energy of Ni–Co MOF is 0.76 eV, which is lower than 1.39 eV of Ni-MOF and 1.00 eV of Co-MOF. The results demonstrate that Ni–Co MOF has a good catalytic effect on polysulfides, which can promote the rapid conversion of polysulfides and once again verify the synergistic effect of Ni–Co MOF on the adsorption and catalysis of LIPSs. In addition, it can be seen that the energy band of Ni-Co MOF has almost no band gap from the calculation based on the slab model, indicating that Ni-Co MOF has good conductivity (Fig. 1v). XRD determined the crystal structure of the Ni–Co MOF. Fig. 3 (a) shows the Ni–Co MOF XRD pattern’s typical reflection [47–50]. An asymmetric cell was assembled to assess the catalysis of the Ni–Co MOF (Fig. 3b). Symmetric cell analysis without the Ni–Co MOF coating showed no redox peaks, indicating pure capacitive behavior. On the other hand, a quasi-reversible peak was observed around 0.338 V for the symmetric cell coated with the Ni–Co MOF, which was assigned to the oxidation of nickel and cobalt species, and a reduction peak around −0.56 V was observed during the negative scan. Hence, the Ni–Co MOF is catalytic toward polysulfides [30]. TG-DTA was used to measure the thermal stability of the Ni–Co MOF (Fig. 3c). The Ni–Co MOF does not start to evaporate quickly until 360 °C with a total mass loss of about 60%. XPS was further employed to characterize the surface chemical information of Ni–Co MOF. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the composites were composed of C, N, O, Ni, and Co. The C 1s high-resolution spectrum (Fig. 3e) can be fitted to three subspectra at 284.78, 285.48, and 288.48 eV, corresponding to C–C, C–O, and C = O, respectively. The three fitted peaks at 398.38, 399.18, and 400.08 eV in the N 1s spectrum were assigned to pyridinic N (N-6), pyrrolic N (N-5), and quaternary N (N-Q), respectively (Fig. 3f). In addition, the three sub-peaks located at 530.48, 530.98, and 531.78 eV representing Co–O / Ni–O, O–H, O–H–O bands, respectively, for the deconvolution of O 1s spectrum, as shown in Fig. 3(g). Fig. 3(h) shows the high-resolution spectrum of Ni 2p, which can be divided into two strong peaks at 879.58 and 855.38 eV are in good agreement with the Ni 2p 1/2 and Ni 2p 3/2 signals in the Ni–Co MOF, respectively. The weak broad peaks at 880.00 and 861.08 eV were caused by the satellite signals Ni 2p 1/2 and Ni 2p 3/2. Similar to Ni, both the Co 2p 3/2 (780.68 eV) and Co 2p 1/2 (796.78 eV) peaks corresponding to CO2+ in the Ni–Co MOF were deconvoluted from the Co 2p spectrum (Fig. 3i). Moreover, the weak broad peaks at 785.99 and 802.28 eV were caused by the satellite signals of Co 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2, implying the coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+. The above results are consistent with the XPS results of the literature Ni–Co MOFs. The porous structure of the Ni–Co MOF was characterized using the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. 3j). The BET surface area value of Ni–Co MOF is 96.7604 m2 g−1. The pore size distribution was 2–50 nm, which can be attributed to mesopores. The hysteresis phenomenon in the low-temperature nitrogen adsorption isotherm is usually related to the capillary condensation in the mesoporous structure. Usually, the hysteresis loops with different shapes are caused by different types of adsorbent and adsorption environments (temperature and pressure). The hysteresis loop of the Ni–Co MOF belongs to the H4 type. The chemical adsorption performance experiments of the prepared samples on Li2S6 were examined to explore the adsorption capacity of the Ni–Co MOF on LiPSs (Fig. 3k). The Li2S6 solution became transparent after adding Ni–Co MOF, which was confirmed by the ultraviolet–visible absorption spectrum. The absorption of Li2S6 solution to visible light is greatly reduced after adding Ni–Co MOF. A lower absorption peak means stronger adsorption capacity, indicating that Ni–Co MOF has a strong absorption capacity for LiPS. EIS was used to measure the conductivity difference before and after LiPS adsorption by Ni–Co MOF (Fig. 3l). The Ni–Co MOF R ct after adsorption was relatively high, which is caused by the poor conductivity of the adsorbed LIPS. XPS tests were performed on the Ni–Co MOF after the adsorption of LiPSs to investigate the chemisorption effect further. XPS survey spectra (Fig. 4 a) show its elemental composition as C, N, O, Ni, Co, S, and Li. O 1s, Ni 2p 1/2, Ni 2P 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2, Co 2p 3/2 peaks slightly shifted towards higher binding energy positions after chemisorption of Li2S6 (Fig. 4b–e). This observation was attributed to the more negative charge of Co and Ni due to bonding between Co, Ni, and S, indicating electron transfer from the LiPS to the Ni–Co MOF. XPS analysis also revealed the metal-sulfur interaction. The Ni–Co MOF shows Co–S / Ni–S bonds in the S 2p spectrum after absorbing Li2S6 (Fig. 4e), indicating that Ni and Co can bond with polysulfides to realize polarity-based chemisorption. Li–O and Li–O–H bonds were detected in the Li 1 s spectrum of the Ni–Co MOF (Fig. 4f), which can be attributed to the Ni–Co MOF and Li + interactions in the LiPSs forming Li–O bonds. The above analysis indicates that the Ni–Co MOF can chemically anchor the LiPSs via Co–S, Ni–S, and Li–O bonds, thus effectively inhibiting the shuttle effect and improving cycling performance. FT-IR spectra also verified the interaction between the Ni–Co MOF and LiPSs (Fig. 2g). All the absorption peaks of Ni–Co MOF after absorbing the LiPSs are shifted to lower or higher wavenumbers, illustrating the strong interaction between Ni–Co MOF and LiPSs. EDS (Fig. 4h) and TEM (Fig. 4i–o) confirmed the presence of S, indicating the adsorption of Ni–Co MOFs on LiPSs. The above analytical measurements show that the Ni–Co MOF immobilizes polysulfides well through physical and chemical synergy. 3.2 Performance analysis of the separators Fig. 5 (a) shows the electrolyte wettability and contact angle of Celgard, PAN, NCMC, and NCMP separators, respectively. The electrolyte on the surface of the Celgard separator was in the form of water droplets because the Celgard separator and electrolyte have poor wettability. On the other hand, the rapid diffusion and wetting of the electrolytes on the surface of the PAN, NCMC, and NCMP separators indicate that porous Ni–Co MOF coatings and 3D nanostructures improve the wettability of the separators to the electrolyte. Notably, the NCMP separator exhibits superior electrolyte wettability with a contact angle of close to zero, indicating an enhanced wettability/affinity of NCMP with electrolyte that is likely conducive to Li-ion diffusion. Fig. 5(b) shows the electrolyte absorption and porosity of the different separators. The PAN, NCMC, and NCMP separators showed better electrolyte uptake and porosity than the Celgard separators. This is due mainly to the high porosity and specific surface area produced by the 3D mesh structure of the electrospun separator and the porous nature of the insertion layer Ni–Co MOF. Furthermore, the nanofibers of NCMP separator coupled abundant polar functional groups, favoring superior electrolyte wettability at the molecular level resulting in high porosity and electrolyte absorption. The high porosity provides more space for electrolyte storage, making more of the electrolyte absorbed by the outer surface of the nanofiber. These results show that PAN, NCMC, and NCMP separators have good electrolyte wettability and affinity for electrolytes, which is conducive to reducing the interface impedance, accelerating the transfer of lithium ions, and improving the ionic conductivity and electrochemical performance. A visible absorption experiment was carried out to see more intuitively the inhibition of the separator on the shuttle effect. Celgard separator, PAN, NCMC, and NCMP separator are in the middle of the H-type electrolytic cell to observe the color change. Fig. 5(c) shows that the solution of the H-type electrolytic cell on the right will gradually become brown after the lithium polysulfide on the left diffuses to the right through the Celgard separator and PAN separator. The phenomenon showed that the Celgard separator and PAN separator could not inhibit the shuttle effect. In contrast, when the NCMC and NCMP separators were placed in the middle of the H electrolytic cell, the color of the right electrolytic cell did not change significantly, which indicates that the composite separator can effectively block the diffusion of lithium polysulfide and inhibit the shuttle effect. TG-DTA was used to examine the thermal stability of the separator. Fig. 5(d) shows the relationship between weight loss percentage and temperature. The weight of the Celgard separator starts to decrease rapidly after 150 °C. On the other hand, the weight of the NCMP separator began to decrease after 280 °C. The heat-shrinking behavior was observed according to the area size change after the separator was placed at 150 °C and 200 °C for 0.5 h. The size of the Celgard separator shrank rapidly to approximately 60% at 150 °C, almost completely melting at 200 °C (Fig. 5e). Nevertheless, the NCMP electrospun separator has no obvious shrinkage at the same temperature. This is because PAN, as a support framework, has excellent heat resistance, which can ignore the area shrinkage caused by high temperature and shows good thermal dimensional stability. These results suggest that the NCMP electrospun separator has high thermal stability. XRD (Fig. 6 a) and FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. 6b) were performed to confirm changes in the chemical composition of the surface of the separators. The FTIR spectra of the NCNC and NCMP separators were similar. The bands at 1560 and 1370 cm−1 are related to the symmetric and asymmetric vibrations of O–C = O, respectively. The band at 1510 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of the C–H group on the benzene ring. The band at 1637 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of the C–C group. Fig. 6(c and d) show the average pore size and pore size distribution of the different separators. The average pore diameter of the NCMC and NCMP separators coated with Ni–Co MOF decreased significantly. The pore diameter of the NCMP separator was mainly approximately 20 nm, and the small pore diameter positively inhibited the shuttle of polysulfides. Moreover, the smaller and uniform aperture distribution plays essential roles in self-discharge. The uniform distribution of pore diameter is conducive to obtaining uniform current density at a high charge–discharge ratio, which significantly inhibits the growth and penetration of lithium dendrites. The N2 adsorption–desorption curves of NCMP separators showed non-overlapping hysteresis loops, indicating that the separators had mesoporous structures (Fig. S2). Fig. 6(f) shows the specific surface area and pore volume of the four separators. The specific surface area and pore volume of NCMC and NCMP separators were significantly higher than those of Celgard and PAN. The extremely high BET surface area strongly showed that the Ni–Co MOF and nanofibers have porous structures consistent with high porosity and electrolyte absorption. In addition, the higher BET surface area and pore structure can provide more reaction sites to promote the capture of polysulfides during electrochemical oxidation and improve the charge storage capacity. Excellent mechanical strength is beneficial in prolonging the service life and safety of Li-S batteries. As shown in Fig. 6(e), the tensile strength of the NCMP separator was 13.15 MPa. The tensile strength of the NCMP separator is high enough to ensure the safety of the battery and avoid damaging the separator during battery assembly. Table 1 lists the separator ionic conductivity (Fig. 6g) and Li+ transfer number (Fig. 6h and Fig. S3) and areal density. The NCMP separator has the highest ionic conductivity and Li+ transfer number, which further confirms the excellent electrochemical performance of the NCMP-modified separator. This was attributed to the high porosity of the NCMP separator, which can accommodate many liquid electrolytes. The excellent retention rate of electrolytes makes lithium ions migrate effectively in the electrolyte, which increases the migration of lithium ions significantly. Porous and well-conductive Ni–Co MOF also helps improve the ionic conductivity and Li+ transfer number. LSV was used to evaluate the electrochemical stability of different separators (Fig. 6i). All separators exhibited similar electrochemical stability, at least up to 4.6 V, which was sufficient for their practical application in Li–S batteries (1.2–3.2 V). In particular, the oxidation current of NCNC and NCMP separators was not observed until 5.0 V, indicating that they have better electrochemical stability and resistance to electrochemical oxidation. Cyclic voltammetry was conducted to determine if the separator could improve the redox reaction rate of Li–S battery (Fig. 6j). The NCMP separator has a sharper redox peak and a larger current, which indicates that the NCMP separator makes the chemical reaction more favorable and rapid in the process of electrochemical reaction, and also indicates that its conversion ability to LiPSs has been improved. This is because Ni–Co MOF has catalytic and adsorption effects on LiPSs. The NCMP separator and electrolyte have better wettability, reducing the internal resistance, which makes the oxidation reaction inside the battery more thorough. A comparison of the potentials of the four separators showed that the potential difference between NCMC and NCMP is 347.5 and 392.6 mV, respectively, which is much lower than that of Celgard (482.7 mV) and PAN (433.8 mV), indicating that the Ni–Co MOF plays a catalytic role in promoting the conversion of LiPSs. Fig. 6(k and l) present the EIS of different separator batteries before and after cycling. The R ct of the four cells decreased after cycling, indicating that the wetting and electrochemical activation of electrolytes were dissolved and redistributed to the active substances. Batteries using NCMC and NCMP showed a smaller R ct than cells using Celgard and PAN, which can be attributed to better conductivity. The intercept in the real axis of the high-frequency range represents the ohmic resistance (R s, including electrolyte and electrode resistance) of the battery. The R s of these four batteries become larger after cycling, indicating that polysulfide shuttles in the separator form a deposited layer on the lithium anode surface. The overall impedance of the NCMF separator battery was small, suggesting that the conductive interlayer inhibits the shuttle effect of polysulfide and improves the interfacial charge transfer of Li–S battery and the reuse of active materials. 3.3 Battery performance The performance of batteries with different separators was evaluated by assembling coin cells. Fig. 7 (a) presents the battery capacity at a different rate. Fig. 7(b and c) show the charging-discharging curves of batteries with Celgard and NCMP separators at different current rates. The battery with the NCMP separator shows the highest discharge capacity under all different current densities. The discharge capacity of the battery using the NCMP separator at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 C rates was 1560, 1353, 1132, 941, 782, 623, and 532 mA h g−1, respectively. Importantly, the discharge capacity is restored to 1457 mA h g−1 when the current rate is switched back to 0.1C, validating a high-rate capability performance of the NCMP battery. The excellent rate performance of Li–S batteries with the NCMP separator proves that the NCMP-modified separator can promote the rapid transport of lithium in the electrochemical cycle. The excellent battery power performance of the NCMP separator can be attributed to the adsorption, blocking, and conversion of the Ni–Co MOF on LiPSs, which effectively inhibits the migration of polysulfides and promotes the redox dynamics of polysulfides. On the other hand, the nanofiber separator has relatively high conductivity and electrolyte absorption. In contrast, the discharge capacity of the battery with Celgard separator at different magnifications was only 1315, 1066, 833, 662, 557, 387, and 272 mA h g−1, respectively. Fig. 7(d) shows the function of NCMP separator in Li–S battery. The high and low temperature resistance of Li–S battery is also an important indicator of practical application safety. The lithium-ion transport kinetics is significantly hindered, resulting in a rapid decline in capacity at low temperatures. The high temperature will aggravate the dissolution of polysulfide, resulting in poor cycle stability of the battery. As shown in Fig. S6, we studied the cycle stability of NCMP battery at different temperatures (5 C for 120 cycles). The cyclic capacity decays of NCMP batteries are 0.076%, 0.057% and 0.095% at 0, 25 and 50 °C, respectively. NCMP battery still exhibits excellent cycle stability under high current and high/low temperature environments, indicating that NCMP separator has high practical potential. In addition, it is noteworthy that the NCMP battery still shows satisfactory electrochemical performance under high sulfur loading and lean electrolyte conditions. As shown in Fig. S5, the NCMP battery still has 87.3% and 81.9% high-capacity retention after 100 cycles when the sulfur loading up to 4.0 mg cm−2 (E/S: 10 μL mg−1) and the low electrolyte is E/S: 5 μL mg−1 (4.0 mg cm−2), respectively. These results imply that the NCMP separator can effectively promote the redox reaction of polysulfides even under high sulfur loading and lean electrolyte conditions. The long-term cycle performance of various separators was tested for 500 cycles at 1 C to assess commercial applications (Fig. 7e). The battery using the NCMP separator provides an initial capacity of 944 mA h g−1. The battery capacity still has 794 mA h g−1, and the capacity retention rate was 84.1%. The lower capacity attenuation was 0.032% per cycle, and the average coulomb efficiency was more than 97% after 500 cycles. On the other hand, the initial cycle capacity of the battery assembled with Celgard separator was 662 mA h g−1. The battery capacity dropped sharply to 171 mA h g−1, and the capacity retention rate was only 25.8% after 500 cycles. The capacity decay rate of each cycle was 0.15%, and the average coulombic efficiency was 92%, indicating a serious shuttle effect in the charge–discharge process of the Celgard separator. These results show the excellent cycling performance of NCMP separators in Li–S batteries. The long-cycle performance at the high current density of 2C was tested to explore the long-cycling stability of the modified separators at high power ratios (Fig. 7f). The battery capacity of the NCMP separator was still 242 mA h g−1 with a decay rate of 0.034% per cycle after 2000 cycles, showing excellent long-term cycling stability. For batteries with Celgard separators, however, the capacity decreased rapidly by only 77 mA h g−1 after 1200 cycles because of the migration of severe polysulfides from positive to negative (Fig. S4). The above results suggested that the battery with the NCMP separator has good structural stability and long cycle life under high currents. The Ni–Co MOF can hinder and catalyze the oxidation and reduction of polysulfides and effectively inhibit the shuttle effect of polysulfides. The porous MOF structures and nanofibers also improve the wettability of electrolytes. Higher electrolyte absorption promotes Li+ migration and ensures rapid Li+ diffusion, contributing to the increased battery capacity and cycle performance. The battery anode after the test (500 cycles at 1 C) was disassembled for characterization to prove the influence of the NCMP separator on polysulfide inhibition and lithium anode. Fig. 8 (b and c) are SEM images of the anode electrode surface of Celgard and NCMP batteries after cycling. The surface of the lithium anode of the Celgard separator after electrical cycling is rough, porous, and uneven, which is caused by corrosion caused by the strong “shuttle effect”. Moreover, the lithium anode was almost covered by polysulfide, suggesting that the Celgard separator cannot block polysulfide, and the battery has a severe shuttle effect. In sharp contrast, the negative electrode corresponding to the NCMP separator still maintains a complete structure, and the corresponding cross-section has no corrosion traces. Only a few particles were observed on the surface morphology, suggesting that the NCMP separator can block more polysulfides and effectively inhibit the shuttle effect. In addition, from EDS analysis of the lithium anode surface after cycling (Fig. 8d–k), the sulfur signal of the battery with NCMP separator was weaker than that of the battery with Celgard separator. The sulfur content of the battery with the NCMP separator was 16.83%, which is far lower than the 39.57% obtained with the Celgard separator, indicating that the NCMP separator can inhibit the “shuttle effect”. 4 Conclusions The synthesized bimetallic Ni–Co MOF was used as a separator-modified material to improve the cycling performance of Li–S batteries. (1) The Ni–Co MOF exhibited strong adsorption and catalysis toward polysulfides, effectively suppressing the “shuttle effect”, accelerating the redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides, and improving the utilization of sulfur so that the battery using the NCMP-modified separator has excellent electrochemical performance. (2) The NCMP electrospun separator also exhibits high thermal stability and electrolyte wettability, which helps improve the electrochemical performance and guarantee the high-temperature safety of batteries. (3) Li–S battery with NCMP separator delivered an initial ultrahigh capacity (1560 mA h g−1) and achieved a remarkable rate capability and long-term stability (794 mA h g−1, 84.1% capacity retention and 0.032% capacity attenuation) over 500 cycles at 1 C. Even at the current density of 2 C, the capacity attenuation rate of 2000 cycles is only 0.034% per cycle. (4) Furthermore, the NCMP-modified separator prevented the corrosion of the lithium anode by polysulfides, thereby increasing the life span of the Li–S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries with high energy density are considered promising energy storage devices for the next generation. Nevertheless, the shuttle effect and the passive layer between the separator and the electrodes still seriously affect the cycle stability and life. Herein, a bimetallic Ni–Co metal–organic framework (MOF) with adsorption and catalytic synergism for polysulfides was successfully synthesized as an electrospinning separator sandwich for Li–S batteries. Introducing porous Ni–Co MOF coatings into the separator provides more adsorption catalytic sites for polysulfides, prevents their diffusion to the anode, and enhances sulfur utilization. Consequently, the improved Li–S batteries with a Ni–Co MOF@PAN (NCMP) electrospun separator delivered excellent rate performance and outstanding cycle stability, yielding an ultra-high initial capacity of 1560 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. Notably, remarkable Li–S battery performance with a discharge capacity of 794 mA h g−1 (84.1% capacity retention) was obtained after 500 cycles, while delivering a low capacity decay rate of 0.032% during long-term cycling (up to 500 cycles) at 1 C. Surprisingly, even at the current density of 2 C, the capacity attenuation rate of 2000 cycles is only 0.034% per cycle. In addition, compared with the Celgard separator, the NCMP separator also had high thermal stability (keeping the separator outline at 200 °C) that ensured battery safety and excellent electrolyte wettability (73% porosity and 535% electrolyte absorption) and significantly enhanced the ionic conductivity and Li+ transfer number, and protected the surface integrity of the anode.
